quotes.quote: It is always possible to argue against anÂ interpretation, to confrontÂ interpretations, to arbitrate between them and to seek for an agreement, even if this agreement remains beyond our reach.
Our interpretations of subjects are clouded by our intellects.
Without theÂ interpretationÂ of the universe by man to the glory of God the whole world would be meaningless.

TheÂ interpretationÂ of a case is corroborated only by the successful continuation of a self-formative process , that is by the completion of self-reflection , and not in any unmistakable way by what the patient says or how he behaves.
AllÂ interpretation, all psychology, all attempts to make things comprehensible, require the medium of theories, mythologies, and lies.
TheÂ interpretationÂ of dreams is a great art.
All things are subject to interpretation whichever interpretation prevails at a given time is a function of power and not truth.
TheÂ interpretationÂ of facts in a certain way stimulates other scientists' thoughts.
The aim ofÂ interpretationÂ is not agreement but understanding.
The supply ofÂ interpretations, like that of advice, greatly exceeds the need for them.
Through interpretation, understanding; through understanding, appreciation; through appreciation, protection.
A common senseÂ interpretationÂ of the facts suggests that a superintellect has monkeyed with physics.
AllÂ interpretations of history are propaganda for one idea or another.
The truestÂ interpretations are those with the best justification.
A falseÂ interpretationÂ of Scripture causes that the gospel of the Lord becomes the gospel of man, or, which is worse, of the devil.
InterpretationÂ is the evidence of growth and knowledge, the latter through sorrow - that great teacher.
AnÂ interpretationÂ exists because of what we find between the notes.
The best way to refine anÂ interpretationÂ is by getting out and performing.
Never trust the translation or interpretation of something without first trusting its interpreter.
TheÂ interpretationÂ of dreams is the royal road to a knowledge of the unconscious activities of the mind.
The art ofÂ interpretationÂ is not to play what is written.
InterpretationÂ is the revenge of the intellectual upon art.

The old style ofÂ interpretationÂ was insistent, but respectful; it erected another meaning on top of the literal one. The modern style ofÂ interpretationÂ excavates, and as it excavates, destroys; it digs 'behind' the text, to find a sub-text which is the true one.
The interpretation of our reality through patterns not our own, serves only to make us ever more unknown, ever less free, ever more solitary.
The chief aim ofÂ interpretationÂ is not instruction, but provocation.
Interpretations, criticisms, diagnoses, and judgments of others are actually alienated expressions of our unmet needs.
We doubt that any facts actually exist. We only have observations andÂ interpretations. Most of theÂ interpretationsÂ remain questionable.
TheÂ interpretationÂ that makes you ardent and hopeful and active and reverent is the true one.
It is ourÂ interpretationÂ of the past, our limiting beliefs, and our undigested pain that stop us from being able to move forward with clear direction.
